summary.p: The news he receives is troubling him; he explains Bullinger's silence on this matter by his work on the commentary on John. Bullinger will be able to learn more about the situation [in the Archdiocese of Cologne] from Bucer's response [No. 1763]. He considers the arrival of the Emperor [in Germany] to be ominous, although he doubts, based on an eyewitness report, whether it is actually Charles [V.]; it is said that he wants to pacify Germany by burning the books of the new believers. [King Francis I] is raging against his subjects; this was told by a young man from Paris, who was thrown out of his house by his father because he possessed a book by Clément Marot - the latter is now staying as a refugee in Geneva, which Gwalther should also know. He is surprised that he writes nothing about the [Zurich students] recommended by Bullinger, [Johann Jakob] Ammann, and Otto [Werdmüller]; for Zurich's sake, he has taken in two of them [Leodegar Hirsgarter and Wolfgang Haller], and placed the others [Rudolf Kopp and Johann Felix Renner] with others. In Schmalkalden, another [federal] diet is taking place, and in Frankfurt, a city diet. Greetings.

div.p: Greetings. There is nothing that affects the emotions of the flesh more at this time than constantly hearing what is happening everywhere. You are overflowing, but you write nothing, which I excuse because of your work on the Commentaries on John, and therefore I take it in good part. Bucer has replied; you will undoubtedly hear from his letters how things stand. I interpret the arrival of the Emperor as fateful. Although I still doubt whether it is indeed the Emperor; I do not assert this, but I doubt. Two Swiss captured by the Spaniards while traveling in Piedmont say, after being released, that he sits on a small horse, is a handsome man, with a beautiful foot, altogether distinguished.

Nothing here fits Charles. I suspect a disguise, which I dare not say because of the Frenchman, who has eyes and ears in the courts of all kings and princes. Therefore, while he is silent, I am forced to be silent as well. But if it is the Emperor, I expect nothing good for Germany. It is certainly said that he will pacify Germany; for he intends to destroy all the books of the new faith by fire.

The Frenchman is not so much increasing persecutions against the evangelicals as he is increasing exactions on his own people. The day before yesterday, a Frenchman from Paris, thrown out of his paternal home, was with me, who told amazing things about the calamities of the French. He was thrown out because of a writing by Clément Marot found in his box by his father; Marot is also in exile in Geneva, which I would like Gwalther to know. I am surprised that he did not say a word about the young men whom you, Ammann, and Otho recommended to me in letters. I do not know what is going on. Two are with me, I have placed the others elsewhere, and indeed faithfully. May they conduct themselves in such a way that they may someday be both useful and honorable to your church! What I do, I do for Zurich's sake, otherwise, I am full of boarders. These young men seem good; for they are very modest.
There are new diets in Schmalkalden, of the cities of Germany in Frankfurt.
May the Lord be present with His word. Amen.
Farewell through the Lord with yours and Theodor and Pellican.
To the most learned Heinrich Bullinger, brother in the Lord. Zurich.
